prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their sister's boyfriend he's not family. The situation involves the sister dating a guy under three months, and the author has concerns about his behavior—drunk driving with her, hanging out with a known ex-felon to buy drugs. The boyfriend started calling the author "brother" and "fam," which annoyed the author.

The author decided to confront him by saying he's not family, which led to the sister not contacting them since. The user thinks the author is in the wrong but wants another opinion.

First, the author's intent: they wanted to set boundaries because the boyfriend was being too familiar. The author's concern about the boyfriend's behavior is valid, but how they addressed it might be the issue. Directly stating that the boyfriend isn't family could come off as harsh, especially considering the sister's choice in partners. The author might have overstepped by not discussing it with the sister first or addressing the dangerous behaviors instead of focusing on the familial terms.

The boyfriend's actions (drunk driving, associating with a felon) are serious. The author could have expressed concern about those behaviors more directly. By focusing on the "family" label, the author might have missed addressing the real risks. However, the author also has the right to set personal boundaries. The confrontation might be seen as necessary to prevent the boyfriend from overstepping, but the method could be questioned. The key points are the safety concerns and the approach taken. The answer hinges on whether the author had the right to set that boundary directly without involving the sister first, or if the approach was too abrupt. Considering all, the author's intent was to protect their sister and set boundaries, even if the method was blunt. So, they might not be in the wrong.
